utterance: Robert Bryan Jr: Um, so let's start uh with introducing ourselves. Um, again, I'll start. I'm Bob Bryan, professor uh at Baylor College of Medicine. utterance: Shikha Nangia (Syracuse University): I can go next. My name is Shikha Nangia. I'm an associate professor in biomedical and chemical engineering at Syracuse University in New York. Uh, I'm a computational biophysicist, biochemist, uh trained as a chemist. Uh, we look at the interaction of uh neighboring cells at the molecular level, looking at tight junction architecture and uh proteins that are embedded on the cell surface. Um, and also I study bacterial cell membranes and bacterial porins, so how the metabolites go in and out of bacterial cells. So I have uh interest both in the blood brain barrier uh architecture and getting drugs into the brain as well as the bacterial cells. Um, so the this is the right uh session for me because we're talking about connecting these two aspects of my research and I'd like to contribute at the molecular level as much as I can to this work, which is very, very important. I'll stop there. Thank you.

utterance: Robert Bryan Jr: So communications between the gut and the brain. And on this breakout group, we have uh a number of questions we can discuss. Um, let me just go ahead and read them.
